transcripts.text: Can you see that?  Just to let everyone know this is my best mate.  Trans people kind of have to grow up more quickly and mature more quickly.  So I'm just used to hanging around with people that are older because I get along with them.  I should be starting T the start of next year.  Yeah, so I came out when I was nine.  I was like quite young when I started Blockers.
Puberty blockers give people like Kai more time to solidify their gender identity without developing secondary sex characteristics.
I had an appointment recently at the Tavistock in London and our second appointment is the second day I go back to school.

I'm hoping for the blockers just to make the whole package, make the whole package really, make me happy and that will be that, I'll be perfect.  If it's too late there's no point of getting blockers because everything's gonna grow anyway.  It needs to happen soon because otherwise It's not going to change anything.  It's not going to work.  So I need to think quick and they need to think quick.
If someone asks me if I am on testosterone or blockers, I'm currently on blockers.  I'll be on testosterone when I'm 14 or 16.
If Kai decides not to transition, his puberty blockers can be reversed by stopping treatment.

There's obviously people at school that are growing some facial hair, you know, getting some guns, but obviously I do feel like I'm falling behind a little bit, like, with my puberty, but, I mean, it's only a little bit left till I start T, so I'm not really worrying about it.

I've been on T for a year and three months now, I think, so I was still on the blocker and still on T at the same time, so it was a bit confusing while they were doing that, but now I'm on the full dough, so I've started growing my facial hair on the sides a little bit.  Actually, you can't really see it here.  My friends have their beards now and I'm just watching them grow up and turning into a man and I just want to be on the same level as them.  I've managed to, I guess, get used to that feeling.

I mean, I always knew that there was something wrong, but because it wasn't, like, so open and out there as it is now, I didn't really know what it was called.  And then I had a counsellor and the only reason I had the confidence to come out was because of him.  He said, draw how you feel, because I wasn't the best at drawing.  talking about my emotions and talking about how I feel.  So I just drew down me with a willy and my guns like this and he showed my mum and my mum obviously didn't want to say anything to me in case I was just being an idiot and she didn't want to put words into my mouth.  So she waited and then about a month later I told her.
Soon as I told her it just got off my chest and I was fine and then she just like helped me with everything.

I mean, I do wish it was earlier, but I'm proud that I even came out at nine.  I was completely, like, crapping myself.  Like, when I went into her room, I honestly thought that it was going to be the end of our relationship.  And then for her to be like, oh, I already knew.  I was just waiting for you to tell me.  And I was like, you've literally made me crap myself, waiting for me to be able to tell you, and you already know.  And then when I told my sister, we went to Yo Sushi.  It's my favourite place.
I've always known from the start you'd be a boy, and I'm glad and proud of what you've turned out to be.  And in the future, what's going to happen next?
I've always, like, grown up, like, being a boy, but I never really knew anything about it.
Like a tomboy, that's what I was like, yeah.
So, obviously, I first, I think, got spoken about it in school and in assembly, and then, obviously, I watched your video.

Before I came out, I was there for only a month.  I wanted to get it, like, just out as soon as possible because there was no point in, for me personally, to wait for it.  to make relationships and then tell them.  Where I used to go a club, he told my form and then everyone started talking about it and now the whole school knows.  So I was there for like a month, made a few friends and then when I told them they were all just fine with it.  So from that point I knew that it was going to be fine like school-wise because I was so scared because I moved from Cheltenham.
The boys discussed binders which helped to flatten the chest.

I like having my stomach tucked in.

Being out and running around crazy with no top on in the sun.

With our hairy legs.
We'll be the best.

No, I don't even know what I want to be anymore.
The main reason I want to be a tattoo artist is because I just love tattoos.  I want to be covered.  So my neck down to my ankles, and then I want to get some of my toes done.
I think I'm going to wait to be a tattoo artist to get my first tattoo done.
Got another four years yet, mate.  That's fine.  I'll wait four years.  You alright?  Just wanted to ask you about like tea and everything.  Were you on blockers when you were younger?
Yeah, I think I was about 12 when I started.
When did you start tea?  Just before my 16th birthday.

January this year I started on the treatment of hormone blockers which just stops all the like the hormones and everything going through.  I have to take them every four weeks and it feels so much better now because you feel like you've kind of stopped And that means you can carry on as yourself and you don't have to go through all the things that biological females would have to.
How many times did you have to go to the tavern to stop and stuff?
Too many.
It is such a long process.  So have you been to the museum?
No, I've never been to a museum of transology before.
Have you gone in them?  Yeah.

Guys, hi!  Hi, I'm E-Jane, lovely to meet you and welcome to the Museum of Transology.  We've got here in the gallery the largest collection of objects and stories in a museum in the world that relate to trans lives.  It's real trans people's stories, by them, about them.  One of my favourites is the one that was actually done by Fox that says gender roles are dead and it's incredibly popular.  We are part of this movement of protest that we're still struggling for equal rights, that we still want to share our experiences and that we're brave enough to do it quite boldly and like put it on our t-shirts.  Have you ever seen anything like this in a museum before?  No, never.  And I think that's the point, isn't it?  Unless we have collections like this, then the only way people are going to find out about trans lives are through the media, right?  And we need our voices to be heard.  Do you recognise what these are?
testosterone, estrogen.

Yeah.  Even though they're all hormones, every single story is different.  And you guys have had experiences as well that are quite unique with your hormone taking, haven't you?  You're about to start.
Should be starting a month before my 16th.
And before your hormones, did you, you started with your blockers?
Oh, yeah.  So I started blockers when I was nine.
The best thing that could have happened to me, really.  And honey, are you excited about the fact that you're nearly 16 then?  Yeah, I am.  I can't wait.  What are you most excited about?
I'm probably most excited about my voice deepening and my beard growing.
Starting on that puberty that you're supposed to be on and then you feel that that's right for you, that is you.  And that's been the best part.

It's such a different experience from what I went through.  I came out as trans, what, 25 years ago or something, and the struggle that I went through having to get my hormones on the black market, you know, not being able to get medical attention, being forced to have psychotherapy, and then as well having to fight what my body had already done to me, you know, and work backwards instead of being positive about moving forwards.
Taylor sees a donation to the museum from his friend Chrissy Bentley, who died by suicide.
Here we've got Chrissy's RAF hat, which I think is really important that it's been kept here and it keeps that history and that memory.

And what I think is really interesting about it is that she's chosen to give us her boy's cap.  because she didn't need it anymore and she makes a joke about it.  So there's that side of Chrissie that we can remember.  that's not just the sadness of her passing, actually the memory that we've got protected is her being funny and cheeky as well.

it's nice you know because obviously everyone's got that kind of non-physical memory of just what a wonderful person she was.  but then you also kind of get that physical history and memory for her as well.
i'm so grateful to her that she that's such an important object for her.  you know it marks such a significant time in her career.  so yeah her memory lives on because of her.
Fox is probably the reason that I actually had the confidence to come out.  So yeah, just seeing these, it's really good.  I remember wearing one of these the first Pride I went to as well.
The Trans Pride?  What's Trans Pride mean to you?
A lot.
Why does it mean a lot?

I can be myself there.  I don't have to worry about, obviously, who's looking at me, what everyone's thinking.  It's also good to see everyone that you don't usually get to see all the time that go specifically to go there.
So, yeah.  You're kind of celebrating the whole time of just being your kind of unique self and everyone being together and celebrating that.
Yeah.
Just kind of having the confidence to kind of go out there and you say, I'm here, this is me, and this is all of us together, and it's fantastic.
I think it's my happiest day of the year.  It's my trans Christmas.  Just seeing everyone so positive.  And like you say, just so many different people.  There's not one trans, you know.
There's different stories as well.

Yeah, just like this collection, right?  We're a really diverse group of people with really diverse experiences.  And sometimes when they come all together, you just feel stronger knowing you're part of a big trans community.  By remembering that we have made progress, we can feel empowered.  To move forward and keep going.  I feel very very hopeful meeting guys like you that that we have a positive bright trans future When we're given this space and we're listened to and we're allowed to control it ourselves.  I feel very positive.  You are the future.  Oh, so I have to stand on my tippy-tails?  Guys, thanks so much for coming.  Next step is that I want something from both of you, okay?  Excellent.  Okay, well, I'm looking forward to that, all right?  It's a promise, yeah?  Great.  Okay, guys.

I reckon just to people that are out there, even if, you know, you're scared and, like, it's hard for you, The best thing for yourself is just to tell whoever you're with.
